content:
The only way to guarantee checking is not done at startup is to launch in Offline mode (Settings/General/Network & Disk Space). After startup, go online manually to check, then go back offline to stop periodic and 'push' notifications.

Consider creating separate profiles for accounts you wish check this way, and accounts that can always be online.

creator: tfox37380

content:
I suggest you disable your antivirus mail scanner and try again. Generally this is an issue only with POP mail accounts. If you are not using POP. Please say so.

There are all sorts of "workarounds" to the fact antivirus products encounter a malformed email and drop dead in their tracks. Sometime a Thunderbird restart will allow them to recover, other time a system reboot is required. But they will continue to drop the ball on every encounter with the mail that has caused the issue in the first place.

There is what David said already, there are suggestions to empty online spam folders (they are most likely to be malformed) but in reality the only sure fire way is to download your mail without the failing antivirus component messing it up. Once the download occurs, you might not have an issue after you re-enable it for years.

Personally I use windows defender and no mail scanner. So I have no issues with antivirus dropping the ball. But many find comfort in having their mail scanned and have to deal with the issues doing so can cause.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
My guess is you are experiencing Thunderbird's default setting since ver 102 to thread messages. You can fix that by changing the sort order to unthreaded. That can be done in two ways. If you have the menu bar (which can be invoked by pressing the Alt key if not visible) , click view>sort by> unthreaded. OR, you can click the icon to the right of the quick filter button above the message list pane and select 'sort by'

To change default for *new* folders, In config editor, you can change default that applies to NEW folders you set up: mailnews.default_view_flags 0 = unthreaded

Config editor is available at Tools>settings>general and scroll to bottom

creator: MattAuSupport

content:
david said
If you just edit the existing account, the setup itself will overwrite your folders. Copy the folders elsewhere prior to setting up the new account to be safe. Then, you can copy back after the new account is established.

I prefer to suggest export using the import export tools. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/?src=ss

It has the advantage of checking the currency of the mail in the folder with the server as part of the export, and is less prone to silent background failures that can occur when dealing with thousands of IMAP mail at one time.

Export to Mbox format handles whole folders at a time and breaks any connection the mail has to the IMAP server, without the user needing to be aware of what is a local store and what is not.

Import is limited to local folders which means there is a copy in Thunderbird, and an external copy should there be any issues moving mail from the local folders to the new account.

content:
Right click the folder, select properties and then the repair button should fix the layout.

I am guessing the problem may be caused by the XNote++ extension

Generally I blame antivirus or other products that change files on the fly, things like cloud backups and streaming backups or storage of the profile folders on a remote server. But there is a background number of folk at the moment having issues, and the lowish numbers indicate either a less popular antivirus (that is not what defender is) but also XNote++ writes to the same index file Thunderbird uses to get the location of the email in the mail store to display it.

If possible it would be good if you disabled it for a time and see if it is the cause. I do not see anything in the open issues on their web site https://github.com/xnotepp/xnote/issues However that only means no one has raised an issue, and given the type of addon XNote is, I would think most folk would struggle without it once they use it. So few will run without it long enough to actually work out it has an issue.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: rspung0711

content:
Is there a support request in there somewhere?

DKIM and DMARC are all setup server side. Generally as a part of the hosting plan for the domain and are configured in DNS with the hosting service. There are no settings for any of that in Thunderbird.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: I received an email from Mailchimp about the changes. I called them and said I need to contact my website host. I called them and they said it was something that our email provider had to set up. Everyone is passing it on to someone else.
creator: store14

content: I have done this before with Mailchimp. If you self-host, it is not difficult to do from cpanel, and is a service that MUST be done to prevent messages from Mailchimp appearing as spam. You may need to escalate to second level of your email host, as most readily understand and will do that.

content:
I would use Revo Uninstaller (Free). BUT be careful! It will call TB uninstaller and when it has finished it will scan for leftover files and registry entries. You have a choice of reg or deep scan. I always do the deep scan if I an having problems; but when I tried this with TB it brought up a whole wack of Wordperfect entries - which I don't want to delete. Usually you can just say "delete all" and it's fine - don't know why it went weird this time. Try a reg scan first. The other thing is that it is a "new and improved" version (like TB!!!) and I am running an older version. I think it's Ver 2.1.7. They have changed the GUI and it's not so easy to get used to. (Maybe unless you are on a cellphone!!) 

       BACKUP FIRST
creator: Harry-Nelson
